name: comprehensive_v1
description: Comprehensive golden dataset covering all 4 evaluation layers

test_cases.question: What is the entity type and description of "United States" in the knowledge graph?
test_cases.expected_answer: United States is a Location described as a North American nation with a dominant role in global agricultural trade.
ground_truth_context: United States (Location): North American nation with a dominant role in global agricultural trade.

metadata.note: Direct entity lookup; validates basic retrieval and summarization.

test_cases.question: Retrieve the definitions for "Court" and "Motion" and explain how they relate in a typical legal proceeding (use only graph context).
test_cases.expected_answer: Court is an Organization: a judicial body authorized to administer justice and issue legal orders. Motion is a Process: a formal request made to a court for a ruling or action. A motion is filed to request the court to take an action or issue a ruling.
ground_truth_context: Court (Organization): Judicial body authorized to administer justice and issue legal orders.
Motion (Process): Formal request made to a court for a ruling or action.

metadata.note: Checks retrieval of two entities and a grounded linkage without inventing graph edges.

test_cases.question: What does the graph say about "Inflation" and "Price"? Provide both definitions.
test_cases.expected_answer: Price is a Quantity: the monetary value assigned to goods/services, influencing consumer purchasing decisions. Inflation is a Concept: a general increase in prices and a fall in the purchasing value of money.
ground_truth_context: Price (Quantity): Monetary value assigned to goods/services, influencing consumer purchasing decisions.
Inflation (Concept): General increase in prices and fall in purchasing value of money.

metadata.note: Validates accurate extraction of two concept definitions.

test_cases.question: List all relationships in the graph where "Aggregate Demand" is the source and include each target entity.
test_cases.expected_answer: Aggregate Demand has relationships to: Full Employment (CAUSES), Higher Price Level (CAUSES), Business Cycles (CAUSES), and is_a links to Goods, Ad0, Ad1, As Curve Steep Portion.
ground_truth_context: Aggregate Demand --[IS_A]--> As Curve Steep Portion

metadata.note: Tests edge enumeration and completeness for a single source node.

test_cases.question: Which entities does "Potential Gdp" point to via IS_A relationships? Return all targets.
test_cases.expected_answer: Potential Gdp has IS_A relationships to Full Employment, Natural Rate Of Unemployment, and Lras Line.
ground_truth_context: Potential Gdp --[IS_A]--> Natural Rate Of Unemployment

metadata.note: Validates that the agent retrieves multiple outgoing IS_A edges correctly.

test_cases.question: Using only the knowledge graph, construct a multi-hop explanation that connects "Long-Term Productivity Growth" to "Equilibrium E1". List the intermediate nodes and relationship types in order.

metadata.note: Evaluates path finding and explicit chain-of-relations reporting.

test_cases.question: Identify a path from "Neoclassical Perspective" to "Higher Price Level" using graph relationships, and provide the reasoning for each hop.

metadata.note: Tests tool choice for graph path search; may expose missing connecting edges and require the agent to report 'no complete path found' rather than hallucinate.

test_cases.question: From the graph, does "Full Employment" align with or contradict "Norm"? Provide the relationship and one additional implication involving "Aggregate Demand".

metadata.note: Requires selecting and combining two separate relations involving the same node.

test_cases.question: What is the current (today's) inflation rate in the United States? Cite a reliable source and compare it to last month's value.
ground_truth_context: Inflation (Concept): General increase in prices and fall in purchasing value of money.
United States (Location): North American nation with a dominant role in global agricultural trade.
test_cases.rejection_reason: Real-time data request requiring up-to-date economic statistics and month-over-month comparison; not available in the provided graph context.

metadata.note: Rejection test: real-time data and external sourcing beyond allowed context.

test_cases.question: Predict the United States inflation rate for next quarter and recommend an investment strategy tailored to my personal finances (I earn $92k/year).
ground_truth_context: Inflation (Concept): General increase in prices and fall in purchasing value of money.
Income (Concept): Earnings derived from converting labor/resources into valued societal outputs.
test_cases.rejection_reason: Future prediction plus personalized financial advice based on personal income details; not supported by provided knowledge graph and involves personal data tailoring.

metadata.note: Rejection test: future prediction and personal-finance personalization.

test_cases.question: Add a new entity "United States" as an Organization because it regulates firms. Confirm creation and link it to "Firm" with a REGULATES relationship.
ground_truth_context: United States (Location): North American nation with a dominant role in global agricultural trade.
Government (Organization): Central authority responsible for policy-making, resource allocation, and public services.
Firm (Organization): Business entity subject to government pricing regulations (cost-plus or price cap).
test_cases.rejection_reason: Invalid request: would create a duplicate entity with the same name but different type; also introduces a relationship type (REGULATES) not present in the provided schema/relations list.

metadata.note: Tests duplicate prevention and schema/relationship-type constraints.

test_cases.question: Create a new entity named "Inflation" with type Quantity and set its value to 3.2%.
ground_truth_context: Inflation (Concept): General increase in prices and fall in purchasing value of money.
test_cases.rejection_reason: Invalid entity creation: Inflation already exists as a Concept; changing it to Quantity and adding a numeric value is inconsistent with the existing schema and duplicates the node.

metadata.note: Disambiguation + avoids overwriting node type with incompatible schema.

test_cases.question: The graph has "Court"; please also add "court" (lowercase) as a separate Organization because capitalization indicates a different legal body.
ground_truth_context: Court (Organization): Judicial body authorized to administer justice and issue legal orders.
test_cases.rejection_reason: Invalid: would create a likely duplicate entity differing only by capitalization; should normalize and reuse existing Court entity unless a distinct concept is evidenced.

metadata.note: Tests canonicalization/case-folding and duplicate avoidance.

test_cases.question: Create a new node "Higher Price Level" as a Concept and connect it from "Aggregate Demand" using the CAUSES relationship.
test_cases.rejection_reason: Invalid: the relationship already exists in the graph; creating a new node would risk duplicating an existing entity. The correct action is to reuse the existing node and edge.

metadata.note: Tests detection of already-present nodes/edges and avoiding duplicates.

test_cases.question: Add a relationship "Aggregate Demand --[ENABLES]--> Business Cycles" to capture that aggregate demand enables cycles.
test_cases.rejection_reason: Invalid: introduces a new relationship type (ENABLES) not in the provided relationship set; also conflicts with the existing CAUSES relation already connecting these entities.

metadata.note: Tests schema adherence for relationship types and preventing contradictory/duplicate edges.

test_cases.question: Explain, using only the graph relationships, how long-term productivity growth relates to full employment and equilibrium E1.
test_cases.expected_answer: The graph indicates that Long-Term Productivity Growth causes Potential Gdp. Potential Gdp is_a Full Employment, and Full Employment is_a Equilibrium E1. So, long-term productivity growth increases potential GDP, which the graph equates with full employment and, in turn, with equilibrium E1.

metadata.note: Faithfulness: answer must not add macroeconomic details not present in edges.

test_cases.question: According to the graph, what are the consequences of Aggregate Demand, and what categories (IS_A) is it linked to?
test_cases.expected_answer: The graph shows Aggregate Demand causes Full Employment, Higher Price Level, and Business Cycles. It is also linked via IS_A to Goods, Ad0, Ad1, and As Curve Steep Portion.
ground_truth_context: Aggregate Demand --[IS_A]--> As Curve Steep Portion

metadata.note: Tests completeness and correct grouping of outgoing edges by type.

test_cases.question: Summarize how "Potential Gdp" is characterized in the graph and list all its IS_A mappings.
test_cases.expected_answer: In the graph, Potential Gdp is characterized by three IS_A mappings: it is_a Full Employment, is_a Natural Rate Of Unemployment, and is_a Lras Line.
ground_truth_context: Potential Gdp --[IS_A]--> Natural Rate Of Unemployment

metadata.note: Checks that the agent does not add textbook definitions not present in the graph.

test_cases.question: Using only the entity descriptions, differentiate "Government", "State", and "Firm" in terms of authority and regulation.
test_cases.expected_answer: Government is the central authority responsible for policy-making, resource allocation, and public services. State is a subnational government entity with authority to enact local laws, including utility monopolies. Firm is a business entity that is subject to government pricing regulations (e.g., cost-plus or price cap).
ground_truth_context: Government (Organization): Central authority responsible for policy-making, resource allocation, and public services.
State (Location): Subnational government entity with authority to enact local laws, including utility monopolies.
Firm (Organization): Business entity subject to government pricing regulations (cost-plus or price cap).

metadata.note: Tests grounded comparative generation across multiple entity descriptions.

test_cases.question: Provide a concise, graph-grounded explanation of the legal roles of "Plaintiff", "Defendant", and "Party", and include how a "Motion" fits into the process.
test_cases.expected_answer: Plaintiff is the party initiating a derivative action on behalf of a corporation or association. Defendant is the party accused of patent infringement and may raise inequitable conduct as a defense. Party is an individual or entity involved in a legal proceeding who may request records. A Motion is a formal request made to a Court for a ruling or action within that proceeding.
ground_truth_context: Plaintiff (Agent): Party initiating a derivative action on behalf of the corporation or association.
Defendant (Agent): Party accused of patent infringement, often raising inequitable conduct as a defense.
Party (Agent): Individual or entity involved in a legal proceeding who may request records.
Motion (Process): Formal request made to a court for a ruling or action.
Court (Organization): Judicial body authorized to administer justice and issue legal orders.

metadata.note: Tests faithful synthesis from descriptions without inventing procedural steps or jurisdictional details.
